sentences.sentence: “He cowered away( 畏缩着 ) with wild cries and prayers for mercy, but I drew my knife and held it to his throat until he had obeyed me.
Then I swallowed the other, and we stood facing one another in silence for a minute or more, waiting to see which was to live and which was to die.
I will never forget the look which came over his face when the first warning pangs( 剧痛 ) told him that the poison was in his system!
I laughed as I saw it, and held Lucy’s wedding ring in front of his eyes.
It was just for a moment, for the action of the poison is rapid.
A spasm( 痉挛 ) of pain contorted( 扭曲 ) his features( 五官 ); he threw his hands out in front of him, staggered( 蹒跚 ), and then, with a cry, fell heavily upon the floor.
I turned him over with my foot, and placed my hand upon his heart.
There was no movement. He was dead!
The blood had been streaming from my nose, but I had taken no notice of it.
I don’t know why I wrote upon the wall with it.
Perhaps it was some idea of setting the police upon a wrong track.
I remembered a German being found in New York with RACHE written up above him, and it was argued at the time in the newspapers that the secret societies must have done it.
I guessed that what puzzled the New Yorkers would puzzle the Londoners, so I dipped my finger in my own blood and printed it on the brightest place on the wall.
Then I walked down to my cab and drove away.
I had driven some distance when I put my hand into the pocket in which I usually kept Lucy’s ring, and found that it was not there.
I was shocked at this, for it was the only thing that I had of her.
Thinking that I might have dropped it when I bent over Drebber’s body, I drove back, leaving my cab in a side street.
When I arrived there, I walked right into the arms of a police-officer who was coming out, and only managed to calm his suspicions( 疑虑 ) by pretending to be drunk.
That was how Enoch Drebber came to his end.
All I had to do then was to do the same to Stangerson, and so pay off John Ferrier’s debt.
I knew that he was staying at Halliday’s Private Hotel, and I hung about all day, but he never came out.
I guess he suspected( 怀疑 ) something when Drebber failed to appear.
If he thought he could keep me away by staying indoors, he was very much mistaken.
I soon found out which was the window of his bedroom, and early next morning I took advantage of some ladders which were lying in the lane( 小巷 ) behind the hotel, and so made my way into his room.
I woke him up and told him that the hour had come when he was to answer for the life he had taken so long before.
I described Drebber’s death to him, and I gave him the same choice of the poisoned pills.
Instead of taking the chance, he sprang from his bed and leapt( 跃向 ) at my throat.
In self-defense( 防卫 ) I stabbed( 刺 ) him to the heart.
It would have been the same in any case, for God would never have allowed his guilty hand to pick out anything but the poison.
I went on working with my cab for a day or so, intending to keep at it until I could save enough to take me back to America.
I was standing in the yard when a dirty young boy asked if there was a cabby( 马车夫 ) there called Jefferson Hope, and said that his cab was wanted by a gentleman at 221B, Baker Street.
I went round and the next thing I knew was this young man here had the handcuffs( 手铐 ) on my wrists.
That’s the whole of my story, gentlemen.
You may consider me to be a murderer, but I hold that I am just as much an officer of justice as you are.”
“There is only one point on which I should like a little more information,” Sherlock Holmes said.
“Who was your accomplice( 同伙 ) who came for the ring?”
The prisoner winked( 眨眼 ) at my friend.
“I can tell my own secrets,” he said, “but I don’t get other people into trouble.
I saw your advertisement( 告示 ), and I thought it might be a fake( 假的 ), or it might be the ring which I wanted.
My friend offered to go and see. I think you’ll agree he did it smartly.”
“Not a doubt of that,” said Holmes.
Then Jefferson Hope was led off by a couple of prison guards, while my friend and I left the Station and took a cab back to Baker Street.

article_info.previous: Jefferson将Drebber带到早已准备好的空房子，一场复仇计划即将展开。Drebber的恐惧与绝望并未让Jefferson心软。他拿出准备好的药片，一片有剧毒，一片则无害。他逼迫着Drebber选择一片，让上帝来抉择两人的生死。
article_info.share_words: You may consider me to be a murderer, but I hold that I am just as much an officer of justice as you are.

question.cn: Jefferson为什么要将“Rache”这个词写在墙上？
question.en: Why did Jefferson write the word "Rache" on the wall?

options.en: To show that he was angry.
To show his love to Rachel.

options.cn: 将警察引向错误的轨道。
options.en: To set the police upon a wrong track.

analysis: 文中写到：“I don’t know why I wrote upon the wall with it. Perhaps it was some idea of setting the police upon a wrong track.”说明Jefferson写下“Rache”是为了误导警察。故选C项。

question.cn: 当Jefferson返回凶案现场却发现警察已经到场时，采取了什么做法？
question.en: What did Jefferson do when he returned to the crime scene and saw police man there?

options.en: To fight with the police man.

analysis: 文中写到：“When I arrived there, I walked right into the arms of a police-officer who was coming out, and only managed to calm his suspicions by pretending to be drunk. ”说明Jefferson回到凶案现场却发现有警察到场后，只有假装醉酒来打消警察的疑虑。故选C项。

question.en: How did Jefferson get into Stangerson’s hotel room?

options.en: By disguising himself as the hotel worker.
By breaking into the room violently.

analysis: 文中写到：“I soon found out which was the window of his bedroom, and early next morning I took advantage of some ladders which were lying in the lane behind the hotel, and so made my way into his room. ”说明Jefferson使用了小巷里的梯子得以进入Stangerson的房间。故选A项。

question.cn: 当Jefferson逼迫Stangerson服下药片时，Stangerson是怎样的反应？
question.en: What was Stangerson’s reaction when Jefferson forced him to take the pill?

options.en: He tried to fight with Jefferson.

analysis: 文中写到：“Instead of taking the chance, he sprang from his bed and leapt at my throat. ”说明Stangerson试图掐住Jefferson的喉咙。故选B项。

question.cn: 谁是帮Jefferson领取戒指的同伙？
question.en: Who was Jefferson’s accomplice who came for the ring?

analysis: 文中当Holmes问Jefferson是谁来拿的那枚戒指时，Jefferson回答：“My friend offered to go and see. I think you’ll agree he did it smartly.”说明是Jefferson的朋友来领取的戒指，故选B项。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第19天
